args: So this is the Halidom. I never thought I'd\nfind myself guest of a human-run castle.
Welcome, Isaac! C'mere, the prince is\nwaiting!
Greetings, Isaac.\nI am {player_name}.\nIt's very nice to meet you.
You hail from the sylvan holy land\nin the north, I am told?
Yes. It is known as Initioâ€”a land steeped\nin history and shepherded by the divine\nguardian of the forest, Yggdrasil.
Ah, right. I heard from Luca and Sarisse\nthat your land prizes the traditions of the\nsylvan people.
As a guardsman of the verdure, I have\ncome here seeking a way to preserve\nour culture for generations to come.

My encounter with Luca and Sarisse has
made me realize that my current methods
have their limits. Thus, I shall remain here
for a time, with your assent.
Of course. You're welcome as long as you\nlike. Are there any places you're interested\nin? I'd be happy to guide you anywhere.
A kind offer, and one I shall accept.\nShow me to a place where disparate\ntraditions unite under a common banner.
I know little of the world beyond the\nemerald wealds of the sylvans, you see.
I would like to learn the ways of the other\npeoples of the world and take them as\nlessons to preserve our own.
An interesting endeavor!\nLuckily, I know just the place.
This here's the pride of the Halidom: our\nworkshop! Here, we have human craftsfolk\nworking alongside rokkan masters.
It's a good place to see the differences\nbetween the two races. I figured it might\nimpart some wisdom.
Hey everyone! Can I have your attention\nfor just a moment?
{player_name}! You sure can!\nWho's our guest, and what's he need\ncrafted?
Ah, actually, we're not here to commission\nanything. Isaac wanted to come and do a\nlittle survey of our workshop facilities.
Oh, so he wants to become an apprentice?\nAt long last, I'll finally have my own little\nnewbie to take under my wing!
Easy, Renee. You've already flustered the\npoor man.
It's unusual for a sylvan to take interest\nin a smithy. Not that I mind, though.
It's A-OK in our book, too. Feel free\nto hang around as long as you like.
You've my gratitude.\nI accept your generous offer.
Gotta increase the fire's heat\nby just two degrees...
You never seen fire before? You've been\neyeballing it pretty hard for a while now.
The use of fire is strictly forbidden in our\nwood. I've never really laid eyes on it.
To us, it is a threat. One wrong move,\nand the forest could be set ablaze in\nbut the blink of an eye.
I actually hold you in high esteem, being\nable to control a fire without flinching.
Rokkans are a little better-equipped to\nhandle the heat than most. We've never\nreally had cause to fear it, honestly.
Booo. Meanie rokkans and your special\nfire privileges. Kinda makes me jealous.
We're human, so I wouldn't say things are\nquite the same for us.
Those red-hot squats that Coach used to\nmake us do still haunt my dreams even\nnow.
Yeah, training by squatting...in the middle\nof open flames. Rough stuff...
Truly?! That is harsh training indeed...
The strength of your fire's life-or-death\nwhen it comes to smithin'. Gotta get it\nreal hot to make your weapons.
Oh, is that the newly finished sword?\nNicely done.
Hee hee. Thanks! Heyâ€”Isaac, was it?\nHere, would you like to hold a freshly\nforged sword? Still hot outta the oven.
This blade... It is so much lighter than I\nsuspected. Exceptionally easy to handle.\nUtterly unlike what we have in Initio.
If it is no imposition, I would like to\nhold a weapon of rokkan make as well.
Sure thing. I think this sword'll help you\nsee the difference.
It does not appear to be all that different\nfrom a human weapon, but... Hm?!
Huh. Didn't think a sylvan could heft it.
It is identical in size to the other sword,\nand yet the weight differs dramatically.
It's all about the way each is made.
For rokkan warriors, a sword like this is\nfeatherweight. Human weapons just don't\nhave enough heft for us, broadly speaking.
That's why rokkans prioritize strength over\nlightness. It's been like that for ages.
Ah. So this, too, is rooted in tradition.
Yep. There've been plenty of changes over\nthe years, though.
Weapons are practical tools. We're\nalways seeking to make them better.
If we let our techniques stagnate,\nwe'd have no choice but to shutter up.\nThat's why we strive to iterate.
After all, I'd hate for everything that's been\nhanded down for so long to come to an end\nwith my generation.
We inherited our skills from our father,\nbut we can't mimic his methods perfectly.
Yep. He had muscle where we don't.\nAnd in smithing, strength can sometimes\nbe part of the game.
That's why we devised a way for the\nthree of us to split up the job.
That way, we could keep the technique\nand name of Regis's workshop alive,\neven after his death.
ï¼‚Many hands make light work.ï¼‚\nThat's our slogan!
I see... So you carry on traditions, while\nincorporating changes based on current\ncircumstances.
(This may be a necessary way of thinking.\nWe, the people of Initio, have avoided\nchange for far too long.)
Thank you. This has been most\neducational. It was indeed the right\ndecision to come to this castle.
(I swear to you that I shall find a way\nto see sylvan culture, yourself included,\ncarried on to future generations.)
